generated_json.title: Assessment
content: The patient has persistent neck pain with radicular symptoms, primarily localized to the upper cervical region, involving C3-C4 and C4-C5 levels. The pain is associated with nausea and headaches. The patient reports minimal relief (20%) from a prior C4-C7 injection, suggesting that the pain source may be more proximal, likely originating from C3-C4 and C4-C5 levels, which are noted to be dynamically spondylotic. The physical exam reveals bilateral neck tenderness and spasms at the base of the skull, with normal short exams. The lack of significant neurological deficits supports a primarily musculoskeletal or facet joint origin, though radicular symptoms remain a consideration. Comorbidities include chronic neck pain with a history of prior NBC (likely a cervical spine procedure).
generated_json.instruction:
Provide a detailed note of the patient's current health status based on the information gathered during the visit. This should be in a single paragraph:
Diagnosis or Differential Diagnosis: List the primary diagnosis or possible diagnoses based on the assessment. Include a differential diagnosis if there is uncertainty or multiple potential causes.
Pertinent Positive and Negative Findings: Highlight key findings from the patient's history, physical examination, and diagnostic tests that support the diagnosis or influence the treatment plan.
Severity or Progression: Describe the severity of the condition, if applicable, and any changes observed since the last visit.
Comorbidities: Note any other existing medical conditions that may impact the patient's current health status or treatment plan.

generated_json.title: Plan
content: Repeat cervical facet injection at C3-C4 and C4-C5 levels bilaterally. Continue pain management and physical therapy. Patient will attend functional therapy. Return to clinic in 4 weeks for follow-up evaluation.
